checkNotNull

Throws a NullPointerException if param is null.

iteratorToArray

public static <T> T[] iteratorToArray(Iterator<T> iter)
Create an array from the (rest of) an iterator's output; this function is horribly inefficient. Please, only use it on small iterators.

Parameters:
iter - the iterator to traverse
Returns:
an array of (the rest of) the iterator's values

slice

public static <T> T[] slice(T[] dstArray,
                            T[] srcArray,
                            int startIndex)
Returns the rightmost portion of an array, Python-style.

Type Parameters:
T - (inferred automatically)
Parameters:
srcArray - the array to copy (shallowly)
startIndex - if positive, the index (from the left) at which to start copying; if negative, we treat this as the index from the right. For example, calling this with startIndex = -2 returns the last two items in the array, if it has that many.
Returns:
a shallow copy of array starting at startIndex; this may return an empty array if the startIndex is out of bounds.

getSliceLength

public static <T> int getSliceLength(T[] srcArray,
                                     int startIndex)
Get a slice's length in preparation for taking a slice. I do not like the fact that I have to use this function, but Java left me with little choice.

Returns:
the length of the array that would result from calling slice(Object[], Object[], int) with the given srcArray and startIndex.
See Also:
slice(Object[], Object[], int)

checkNullOrNotInstance

public static <T> T checkNullOrNotInstance(T goodInstance,
                                           Object obj)
Handles the boilerplate null and isinstance check for an equals method. Example: 
 public boolean equals(Object obj) {
     MyClassName that = checkNullOrNotInstance(this, obj);
     if (that == null) {
         return false;
     }
     //...
 }

Parameters:
goodInstance - a non-null instance of type T; looks neater than passing in goodInstance.getClass()
obj - the object to test
Returns:
null if obj is null or not an instance of goodInstance's class; otherwise, we return obj cast to goodInstance's type

safeToString

public static String safeToString(Object obj)
Safely converts an object to a String.

Parameters:
obj - to convert; may be null
Returns:
"null" if obj is null, obj.toString() otherwise

smartRemoveDuplicatesAndNulls

public static <T> void smartRemoveDuplicatesAndNulls(List<T> list)
Remove nulls and duplicate items from the list. This may change the list's ordering. It uses the items' equals methods to determine equality. Advantages over HashSet: This consumes no unnecessary heap-memory, nor does it require objects to implement hashCode. It is OK if (o1.equals(o2) does not imply o1.hashCode() == o2.hashCode()). Advantages over TreeSet: This does not require a comparator. Disadvantages over HashSet and TreeSet: This runs in O(n*n) time.

Parameters:
list - the list to modify; this is fastest with ArrayList.

smartRemoveDuplicatesAndNullsHelper

public static <T> void smartRemoveDuplicatesAndNullsHelper(List<T> list,
                                                           int startIx,
                                                           T objSeenPreviously)
Helper method for smartRemoveDuplicatesAndNulls that is subject to change; if you call this directly, you do so at your own risk!

Parameters:
list - the list to modify; if all items from startIx to the end are either null or equal to objSeenPreviously, then we truncate the list just before startIx.
startIx - the index to examine; we only move items within the range of [startIx, list.size()-1].
objSeenPreviously - the object with which to compare list[startIx]; may be null.
